issues.text: whether there is a binding, valid and concluded contract between the appellants and the respondents

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether there is a binding, valid and concluded contract between the appellants and the respondents.

issues.text: whether there was a concluded contract, and if there was one, whether the mandatory requirements of Article 299 of the Constitution for entering into a valid and binding contract have been satisfied

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question which arises for determination is whether there was a concluded contract, and if there was one, whether the mandatory requirements of Article 299 of the Constitution for entering into a valid and binding contract have been satisfied?

issues.text: apart from the contention relating to Art. 299 of the Constitution, there was no concluded contract between the parties, because (a) the essential terms were not agreed to between them on the date when the acceptance letter was issued by P. C. Oak on 15-7-68, and (b) even if there was an acceptance as alleged, that acceptance was conditional upon a formal contract being executed by the appellants

anchor.surface_text: Two submissions were urged on behalf of the appellants, namely (1) that apart from the contention relating to Art. 299 of the Constitution, there was no concluded contract between the parties, because (a) the essential terms were not agreed to between them on the date when the acceptance letter was issued by P. C. Oak on 15-7-68, and (b) even it there was an acceptance as alleged, that acceptance was conditional upon a formal contract being executed by the appellants

issues.text: the three mandatory requirements of Art. 299 of the Constitution for a valid and binding contract made in exercise of the executive power of the Union have not been complied with namely, (a) that the contract was not expressed to be in the name of the President, (b) was it executed on behalf of the President, or (c) by a person authorized to execute it on his behalf

arguments.claim: the Secretary to the Railway Board, on whose behalf the offer of the Respondents was accepted, was not the person authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President of India

anchor.surface_text: In this case, we are of the view that the Secretary to the Railway Board, on whose behalf the offer of the Respondents was accepted, was not the person authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President of India.

arguments.claim: the only person authorized to enter into the contract on behalf of the President is the Director, Railway Stores

anchor.surface_text: There is little doubt that the only person authorized to enter into the contract on behalf of the President is the Director, Railway Stores.

arguments.claim: authority to execute contracts may be conferred on a person not only by rules expressly framed and by formal notifications issued in this behalf but may also be specifically conferred

anchor.surface_text: This Court had in Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India, earlier held that the authority to execute contracts may be conferred on a person not only by rules expressly framed and by formal notifications issued in this behalf but may also be specifically conferred.

arguments.claim: affidavit evidence shows Director instructed acceptance, and Secretary had status of Director
arguments.court_reasoning: file shows endorsement refers to Board's orders, not Director's; no initials/signature of Director on letter; Secretary not Director

holdings.text: there is no valid or binding contract because the letter of acceptance, on the evidence before us, is not by a person authorized to execute the contracts for and on behalf of the President of India
holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming formalities for concluded contract met, invalid due to lack of authorization under Art. 299 as acceptance by unauthorized Secretary, Railway Board

holdings.text: the Secretary to the Railway Board, on whose behalf the offer of the Respondents was accepted, was not the person authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President of India

anchor.surface_text: In this case, we are of the view that the Secretary to the Railway Board, on whose behalf the offer of the Respondents was accepted, was not the person authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tender notice, conditions, and draft contract specify Director, Railway Stores as authorized; notifications do not cover Secretary

holdings.text: the only person authorized to enter into the contract on behalf of the President is the Director, Railway Stores

anchor.surface_text: There is little doubt that the only person authorized to enter into the contract on behalf of the President is the Director, Railway Stores.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly stated in general conditions, default clause, instructions to tenderers, and draft contract

holdings.text: the letter of acceptance dated 15-7-1968 was on behalf of the Secretary, Railway Board, who is not authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President

anchor.surface_text: In this case the letter of acceptance dated 15-7-1968 was on behalf of the Secretary, Railway Board, who is not authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed 'for Secretary, Railway Board'; no evidence of ad hoc authorization

holdings.text: A contract whether by a formal deed or otherwise by persons not authorized by the President cannot be binding and is absolutely void

anchor.surface_text: It is not settled by this Court that though the words expressed and executed in Article 299 1 might suggest that it should be by a deed or by a formal written contract, a binding contract by tender and acceptance can also come into existence if the acceptance is by a person duly authorized on this behalf by the President of India. A contract whether by a formal deed or otherwise by persons not authorized by the President cannot be binding and is absolutely void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory requirements of Art. 299(1); non-compliance renders void; applies precedents

holdings.text: relayable rails are part of the stores

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept this argument because in our view relayable rails are part of the stores. It may be that some of these rails which are part of the stores may be considered to be in a condition which the authorities concerned think should be disposed of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of clause 9 covering stores including relayable rails offered in tender

holdings.text: clause 43 of Part XVIII has no application as clause 9 specifically covers contracts connected with the sale of scrap, stores including relayable rails

anchor.surface_text: This submission is untenable because clause 9 specifically provides for the contracts connected with the sale of scrap, ashes, coal, dust, empty containers and stores. The tender, it will be observed, is for rails which are scrap as well as rerollable and relayable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific clause 9 prevails over general clause 43

holdings.text: at the relevant time the Secretary to the Railway Board did not have any status as Secretary to the Central Government or Joint Secretary

anchor.surface_text: Even this submission lacks validity because as pointed out on behalf of the appellant, at the relevant time the Secretary to the Railway Board did not have any status as Secretary to the Central Government. The status of a Joint Secretary was only conferred on him by a notification by the Government of India in the Ministry of Railways for the first time on 15-9-1969

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification conferring status post-dates acceptance; affidavit evidence

holdings.text: there is no material before us to conclude that the Board was so authorized

anchor.surface_text: This submission also is without force because there is no material before us to conclude that the Board was so authorized.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence of authorization for Railway Board members

holdings.text: the endorsement does not show that the letter of acceptance was issued on the orders and directions of Mubayi; it shows Board's orders; letter lacks Director's initials or signature
holdings.reasoning_summary: File review rejects additional affidavit evidence claiming Director's instructions

holdings.text: the appeal is allowed and the application under section 20 of the Arbitration Act is dismissed
holdings.reasoning_summary: No valid contract hence no arbitration agreement

holdings.text: it is unnecessary to consider whether all the essential terms had been agreed or contract concluded by acceptance letter or formal contract condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: It is in our view unnecessary to consider the several contentions as to whether all the essential terms of the contract had been agreed to or that the contract was concluded by the acceptance letter of 15th July 1968 or whether the parties intended it to be a term of the contract that a formal contract should be entered into between them in order to bind the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as authorization defect dispositive

In this case, we are of the view that the Secretary to the Railway Board, on whose behalf the offer of the Respondents was accepted, was not the person authorized to enter into a contract on behalf of the President of India.
In this view the appeal is allowed and the application under section 20 of the Arbitration Act is dismissed but there will be numberorder as to companyts of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It is not settled by this Court that though the words expressed and executed in Article 299 1 might suggest that it should be by a deed or by a formal written contract, a binding contract by tender and acceptance can also come into existence if the acceptance is by a person duly authorized on this behalf by the President of India. A contract whether by a formal deed or otherwise by persons not authorized by the President cannot be binding and is absolutely void.
In this view the appeal is allowed and the application under section 20 of the Arbitration Act is dismissed but there will be numberorder as to companyts of the appellants.
